div.head: [Unknown author,letter, September13 [1863?]
div.opener:
Emory College, Oxford, Ga. Sept. 13, '63
Bro Jes'
div.p: I received yours a few days since. It offerded me much pleasure to hear from you as it has been some time since I had received a letter from you before.

I have again commenced the term with as bright hopes and prospects as ever. And the farther that I advance in the dark, yet pleasant road, of science and literature and behold its hidden misteries the greater the necessity - I see of understanding then, as well as the desire of an education. These acting as incentives serves the reader my mind content and a College life agreeable.

That which once was irksome has now become a pleasing duty. Nothing renders me as agreeable as that of study. I do not intend to convey the idea that I have become over studious for there is yet leasure leisure enough for social enjoyments with my college companions. I refer to my companions because if my enjoyment was not with them it would be very little pleasure that it would fall to my lot to experience, for I assure you that the pleasure that I enjoy from female association is but little as it is very seldom that
I even visit there oingowing to two very good reasons, I say good reasons, i don't know that any thing is a good reason why a young man should not occasionaly visit the ladies yet reasons such as I have are sufficient to prevent me in a great measure: my reasons are first my own temiditytimidity, which i know i indulge to a fault, the other is that I never neglect my textext books for the enjoyment of pleasure. My advantages for social enjoyment is better this term than it has been before this oing the paychange in my place of hound. I have left the hotellhotel and take board in a private family where there are two very pleasant young ladies, which may be the means of improvement to me, as well as being a pleasure.
This term has opened under very favorable auspicies. TherThere are now in attendance about one hundred and forty students, and still they come.

One more was aded to our number to day, Emory is growing very popular especially with the Alabamans for the number from that quarter has increased considerably. It was thought that Dr Means leaving us would work very much against the institution, but I do not see that it has injured it at all, but on the other hand our number has been greatly increased, Taking this into consideration and also our superior College building the time is not for asitant when it will considered as great honor to have it to say that I am a son of Emory. Our neighboring College of Covington is also in a state of great prosperity.
I believe the day is not for distant when it will be one of the first female institutions of Georgia.
Its numbers now between eighty and a hundred students, Dr. MeansDr. Means is now at its head. His fame as an istructor will add much to the importance of the institution.

Politics is raging very high through this section especially in this county, Great excitement up licker question. The preminent taking sides for and some against are three sets of candidates out for one for legislation, one against it, cal issues of the day.
